title: Elena Delle Donne wins WNBA MVP for historic year with Mystics
text:
The chants materialized sometime during the summer, a hopeful signal of what could come. Then they repeated, game after game until Sept. 8, when a near-full crowd at the Washington Mystics’ regular-season finale called out to Elena Delle Donne: “M-V-P! M-V-P!”

It was “something that gives you chills,” Delle Donne said later. “I absolutely love this city and there’s nowhere I’d rather be. For them to have my back like that really means a lot. It was a special moment.”

Delle Donne was named the WNBA’s Most Valuable Player on Thursday for the second time, following the most dominant and well-rounded season of her career.

She received 41 out of 43 first-place votes from the national panel of voters in sports media.

Delle Donne ranked second in the league in scoring with 19.5 points per game and ranked fifth with 8.3 rebounds per game, the only player to make the top five of both categories. She became the first woman to join the “50-40-90 Club” by shooting a career-best 51.5% from the field, 43% from 3-point range and a ridiculous 97.4% from the free-throw line — the highest qualifying mark the WNBA has seen in 10 years.

She also averaged 2.2 assists and 1.3 blocks per contest.

She achieved all this while playing through two injuries. After suffering a bone bruise in her knee that hobbled her in the 2018 playoffs, Delle Donne missed the first game of 2019 with knee soreness. She also broke her nose in the first minute of a game in July, causing her to miss the rest of the game and the following two.

The Mystics went 0-4 in games Delle Donne wasn’t available and 26-4 with the star, on their way to setting a new mark for the best record in franchise history at 26-8. Time has passed since her injuries, but Delle Donne continues to wear both a knee brace and a face mask when she takes the court.

The season-long favorite to win MVP, Delle Donne, 30, also was named the Associated Press Player of the Year last week and was an All-Star for the sixth time.

Delle Donne first won the award in 2015 with the Chicago Sky and is now the first WNBA player to win MVP with two different teams. Earlier this year she said it would be “amazing” to win the award as a Mystic.

“When you get an award like that, it’s never an individual award. This isn’t an individual sport,” she said. “[My teammates are] the ones that have really made this such a great season.”

Delle Donne is the third athlete representing a Washington team to win league MVP this decade, joining Bryce Harper and Alex Ovechkin.

Emma Meesseman explained Monday how certain she and her Mystics teammates were that Delle Donne would win the crown.

“People say she’s in the talks of MVP,” Meesseman said. “Like, there’s no talks. She is the MVP.”

While the personal accolades mean a lot to Delle Donne, now she is vying for a piece of hardware she’s never won before: a WNBA championship trophy. The Mystics lead the Las Vegas Aces 1-0 in their league semifinal series and host Game 2 Thursday night.

description: Washington Mystics star Elena Delle Donne was named WNBA Most Valuable Player on Tuesday for the second time, following the most dominant and well-rounded season of her career.
